Thousands vote early at UNC

Turnout for the midterms is low compared to 2008 presidential election

  • 11.9 percent of registered voters turn out early
  • 42 percent of registered voters turned out in 2008
  • Morehead Planetarium registers 5,000 ballots by 5 p.m. Oct. 29

Orange County Democratic Party volunteer Anne Thomas, left, discusses voter registration with a UNC student.

Photo by REBECCA PUTTERMAN REESENEWS
  • By Rebecca Putterman
  • reesenews managing editor
Nov. 01 2:00 am
  • 2322one commenthttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F2010%2F11%2F01%2Fearly-voter-turnout%2F2322%2FThousands+vote+early+at+UNC2010-11-01+02%3A00%3A58Rebecca+Puttermanhttp%3A%2F%2Freesenews.org%2F%3Fp%3D2322
  • E-mail
  • Print

Do you like this story?

Due to an editing error, this article misquoted Phillip Cannon. The article has been changed to reflect this correction.

CHAPEL HILL
A line stretched around the marble pillars of the ornate atrium at the Morehead Planetarium, down its picturesque stone steps and past the manicured front lawn toward McCorkle Place as voters waited more than an hour to cast their ballots early for Tuesday’s election.

By 5 p.m. Friday, Oct. 29, the last day of early voting at the planetarium, more than 5,000 people had cast their ballots.

Out of approximately six million registered voters in North Carolina, 734,459 people cast ballots during the early voting period between Oct. 14-30, according to the N.C. Board of Elections. Only 11.9 percent of the state’s registered voters came out before election day as compared to the 42 percent of registered voters that voted early in 2008.

Nevertheless, passionate citizens turned out to give of their timen by waiting in line or passing out campaign literature.

“I just think it’s very important that we care about whose running things,” said Anne Thomas, a Chapel Hill resident.

Thomas stood at the Orange County Democratic Party table, handing out candidate and voting information just a few feet away from a sign that prohibited any campaigning from going past the steps to the planetarium.

Voters who had persevered through the hour-long wait came back to chat with Thomas, recycling their Democratic sample ballots, and students asked for registration forms to vote for the first time ever or the first time away from home.

Freshman Lizzie Cox, a member of UNC-CH College Republicans, spent her Friday afternoon passing out sample ballots for Conservative voters.

“It’s definitely more Democratic,” she said of the crowd voting at the planetarium. “But still a fair number take Conservative ballots. No one has been rude today.”

Cox stood in front of a campaign sign for U.S. Sen. Richard Burr (R-N.C.), the candidate she has chosen to support with volunteer efforts.

“He needs everyone to come out and vote; it’s gonna be a close race,” Cox said of the race between Burr and his Democratic challenger, N.C. Secretary of State Elaine Marshall.

Heading into the last full day of campaigning, Burr leads Marshall 55 percent to 42 percent, according to polling data by The New York Times’ Nate Silver on the FiveThirtyEight blog.

Cox admitted that living in Orange County, which tends to vote Democratic, might have skewed her perception of the Senate race.

It was freshman Phillip Cannon’s first time voting. He had already registered in Pitt County but changed his registration to Orange County when he forgot to vote during fall break.

“I’m not gonna make the mistake to not vote the first time,” Cannon said, registration papers in hand. “It’s one of those things you wait 18 years to do, so you might as well.”

The line was comprised of approximately two-thirds students and one-third community members.

Lorraine Conway of Durham waited behind Cannon. She had already voted in Durham County but came to campus to make sure her son, a Chapel Hill resident, got to the polls on time.

“I feel like the only way you have the right to complain is if you do vote,” Conway said.

Conway said she was primarily concerned with making sure that Marshall unseats Burr.

“I don’t feel like Richard Burr has done a good job, like helping unemployed get jobs and extending unemployment,” Conway explained.

While Conway voted in the 2008 presidential election, she said she doesn’t usually bother to turn up for midterm elections.

“I voted this time because I didn’t like what I saw on TV.”

Rebecca Putterman, a senior from Raleigh, N.C., is managing editor for the Reese Felts Digital News Project.

  1. Hi, I am Phillip Cannon.
    I feel I incorrectly quoted in this article. I am pretty sure I did not say the lines to which I am credited. If you read the following sentences, it might become more clear that Conway made the starred comment. I also did not vote in the 2008 election because I was under 18 at the time of the election. Furthermore, I am not female. I know it is not that big of a deal, but I just thought I would let you know.
    Conway said she was primarily concerned with making sure that Marshall unseats Burr.
    * “I don’t feel like Richard Burr has done a good job, like helping unemployed get jobs and extending unemployment,” Cannon explained.
    While Cannon voted in the 2008 presidential election, she said she doesn’t usually bother to turn up for midterm elections.

    I hope this is helpful.

    Comment by Phillip Cannon on November 21, 2010 at 7:39 pm
